questions.text: A middle-aged lady 30-year-old woman complains of diplopia and drooping eyelids. She undergoes investigation which reveals a mediastinal mass. The symptoms of muscle weakness in this patient are caused by antibodies directed against which of the following cellular components?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetylcholine receptor

Option C:

Myasthenia gravis is a type II hypersensitivity disorder caused by antibodies that bind to the acetylcholine receptor. These antibodies interfere with the transmission of neural impulses at the neuromuscular junction, causing muscle weakness and easy fatigability. External ocular and eyelid muscles are most often affected, but the disease is often progressive and may cause death by respiratory muscle paralysis.

Acetylcholine receptor: Antibodies directed against the acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction are characteristic of myasthenia gravis. This condition often presents with ocular symptoms like diplopia and ptosis and may be associated with a thymoma.

Explanation:

Option A: Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor: Antibodies against the TSH receptor are characteristic of Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder that leads to hyperthyroidism, not typically associated with muscle weakness.

Option B: Calcium channel: Antibodies to calcium channels is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which can cause muscle weakness; however, the presence of a mediastinal mass is more suggestive of thymoma associated with myasthenia gravis.

Option D: Rheumatoid factor: Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody observed in rheumatoid arthritis, which primarily affects joints and is not typically involved in the neuromuscular transmission pathology seen in myasthenia gravis.

Educational Objective:

The presence of a mediastinal mass and symptoms such as diplopia and ptosis in a young adult are highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis, which is caused by autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor, leading to muscle weakness.

choices.text: Diminished calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Antibody against the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Accelerated uptake of the neurotransmitter at the nerve-muscle junction
Antibody against presynaptic channels at the nerve-muscle junction

questions.text: A 67-year-old male with a history of smoking and a recent diagnosis of small-cell lung carcinoma presents with a chief complaint of increasing weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles of his limbs. He reports that the weakness improves with repeated use of the muscles. Electromyography reveals a decremental response in muscle action potential amplitude with low-frequency stimulation, which improves with high-frequency stimulation. Mechanism of muscle weakness in Lambert-Eaton syndrome is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans D) Antibody against presynaptic channels at the nerve-muscle junction

 

Option D:

 

  • The clinical scenario, weakness in the proximal muscle groups, associated with a pulmonary neoplasm with metastases, is consistent with Lambert-Eaton syndrome associated with small-cell carcinoma. In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the tumor causes the production of an antibody directed against the presynaptic calcium channels.

 

Antibody against presynaptic channels at the nerve-muscle junction is the correct mechanism. In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, antibodies target the voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic terminal, impairing the release of acetylcholine, and thus leading to muscle weakness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Diminished calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum would affect muscle contraction but is not the mechanism of muscle weakness seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

 

Option B: An antibody against the sarcoplasmic reticulum is not associated with Lambert-Eaton syndrome. Antibodies in LEMS are directed against voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic nerve terminal, not against the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option C: Accelerated uptake of neurotransmitter at the nerve-muscle junction would likely lead to a decrease in available neurotransmitter for muscle contraction, but this is not the pathophysiology of Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscle weakness in Lambert-Eaton syndrome is due to antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels at the nerve-muscle junction, impairing acetylcholine release.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1226
